section.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Perfect Simple for actions which started in the past and continue now. Make the Present Perfect Simple with have/has + past participle.
section.text1a: She has lived here for ten years.
section.text2a: I haven't seen the new film yet.
section.sectiontitle2:
Use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasise that the action isn't finished.
Make the Present Perfect Continuous with have/has + been + -ing form.
section.text3a: I've been reading this book for months.
section.text4a: They have been playing outside for hours.

section.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Perfect Continuous for recently finished activity with present results (often visible).
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasise the activity not the result, often with How long...?
section.text3a: How long have you been learning the piano?
section.text4a: How long has she been swimming?
